cell.html: Served three full terms, died early in his fourth term. His first term in office (1933-1937) was the shortest term for an elected President who did not die in office or resign. This is because in 1937, Inauguration Day for the U.S. Presidency was moved to January 20 from March 4 . So, Roosevelt's first term lasted from March 4 , 1933 until January 20 , 1937 . He was consequently the first President to be inaugurated on January 20 .
cell.text: Served three full terms, died early in his fourth term. His first term in office (1933-1937) was the shortest term for an elected President who did not die in office or resign. This is because in 1937, Inauguration Day for the U.S. Presidency was moved to January 20 from March 4 . So, Roosevelt's first term lasted from March 4 , 1933 until January 20 , 1937 . He was consequently the first President to be inaugurated on January 20 .

cell.html: Served two full terms, not consecutively. Not reelected on first try for a second term. [1]
cell.text: Served two full terms, not consecutively. Not reelected on first try for a second term. [1]

cell.html: Served two full terms, but the first-term inaugural was postponed because the U.S. Congress had not properly convened.
cell.text: Served two full terms, but the first-term inaugural was postponed because the U.S. Congress had not properly convened.

cell.html: Served the remainder of Franklin Roosevelt's term, elected to a full term.
cell.text: Served the remainder of Franklin Roosevelt's term, elected to a full term.

cell.html: Served the remainder of McKinley's term, elected to a full term. Four years after leaving office, ran again and lost.

cell.html: Assassinated early in his second term; his first term was without a leap year , as years that are a multiple of 100, but not 400 are not leap years. The skipped leap year in this case was 1900 .

Assassinated early in his second term.

cell.html: Served one full term without a leap year (years that are a multiple of 100, but not 400 are not leap years). The skipped leap year in this case is 1800 . Not reelected for second term.
cell.text: Served one full term without a leap year (years that are a multiple of 100, but not 400 are not leap years). The skipped leap year in this case is 1800 . Not reelected for second term.

cell.html: Served the remainder of William Harrison's term. Denied renomination by the Whigs, Tyler flirted with the Liberty Party, but was persuaded not to run by the Democrats (his former party). [5]
cell.text: Served the remainder of William Harrison's term. Denied renomination by the Whigs, Tyler flirted with the Liberty Party, but was persuaded not to run by the Democrats (his former party). [5]

cell.html: Served the remainder of Lincoln's term. Sought the Democratic nomination in 1868, but was unsuccessful. [5]
cell.text: Served the remainder of Lincoln's term. Sought the Democratic nomination in 1868, but was unsuccessful. [5]

cell.html: Served the remainder of Garfield's term. Sought a full term, but was not re-nominated. [5]
cell.text: Served the remainder of Garfield's term. Sought a full term, but was not re-nominated. [5]

cell.html: Served the remainder of Taylor's term. Sought the Whig nomination in 1852, but lost to Winfield Scott . Four years later, ran again (as a Know Nothing ) and came in third. [5]
cell.text: Served the remainder of Taylor's term. Sought the Whig nomination in 1852, but lost to Winfield Scott . Four years later, ran again (as a Know Nothing ) and came in third. [5]

cell.html: Served the remainder of Nixon's term. Not elected for full term. [5]
cell.text: Served the remainder of Nixon's term. Not elected for full term. [5]

cell.html: Died in his first term. Did not take the oath of office until March 5, 1849, because March 4th fell on a Sunday and Taylor declined to take the oath on Sunday because of his religious beliefs.
cell.text: Died in his first term. Did not take the oath of office until March 5, 1849, because March 4th fell on a Sunday and Taylor declined to take the oath on Sunday because of his religious beliefs.

cell.html: Assassinated within less than a year of his first term.
cell.text: Assassinated within less than a year of his first term.

cell.html: Died within a month of his first term.
cell.text: Died within a month of his first term.

context.text: List of United States Presidents by time in office - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
# in office President Length in days Rank by length of term Explanation
Shortest presidency 31 days William Henry Harrison in 1841
List of United States Presidents by time in office
Longest presidency 4,422 days Franklin D. Roosevelt from 1933 to 1945
[ edit ] Rank by time in office
[ edit ] Rank by time in office

This is a list of United States Presidents by time in office . The basis of the list is the difference between dates ; if counted by number of calendar days all the figures would be one greater, with the exception of Grover Cleveland who would receive two days.

According to the 22nd Amendment , no President may serve longer than a decade (period of ten years) (2 terms plus a maximum of 2 years having acceded as President under some other President's term). This means that Franklin Delano Roosevelt will always be the number one in the record unless the 22nd Amendment is changed or repealed .
List of United States Presidents by time in office

His first term in office (1933-1937) was the shortest term for an elected President who did not die in office or resign. This is because in 1937, Inauguration Day for the U.S. Presidency was moved to January 20 from March 4. So, Roosevelt's first term lasted from March 4, 1933 until January 20, 1937. He was consequently the first President to be inaugurated on January 20.
